BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 30, 1914.

'VARSITY LOSES TO ST. JOHN'S

FIRST COTILLON FRIDAY NIGHT
The Opening Dance Will Continue Until
12.30 A.M. Louie's Orchestra to
Begin Playing at 8.30 P.M.

The large percentage of the student body who believe, as does a
Baltimore instructor not unknown
to fame, that "dancing is a fine art,"
will be afforded an unusually attractive opportunity to exercise the
"light fantastic toe," when the
sweet seductive notes from Louie
Fisher's orchestra usher in the first
cotillon of the season Friday night.
Eight-thirty has been set is the
time for the opening of festivities,
which, in accordance with a special
dispensation from the Powers that
Be, will continue until thirty minutes of Saturday morning have
flown by. How this arrangement
.will please the numerous janitors
and gentlemen-in-waiting has not
as. yet been ascertained, but all
other parties intimately concerned
have expressed their heart-felt approval. It was the desire of the
Cotillon Board that one o'clock
might be the closing hour, but half
a loaf is so decidedly better than
none, that the gaining of an extra
half-hour is regarded as a conquest
of no mean importance.
The cotillon will consist of twenty
dances, of which the tenth and
eleventh will be supper dances.
Every fourth dance, throughout the
evening, will be a waltz, in order
that the few unfortunates who
have not yet entirely mastered the
mysteries of the elusive fox-trot
may not feel utterly abandoned and
apart. Those who by dint of exceeding great effort have reached
this pinnacle of accomplishment,
however, will by no means be forgotten, and the best efforts of
Louie's orchestra will be devoted to
their entertainment and delight.
The veteran leader in many a
hard-fought cotillon has promised
to procure the very latest and best
dance music from New York to
grace this gala occasion, and the
persuasive powers of his melodious
band of satellites are too well
known to require comment. All
things considered, the, prospect for
an affair that will pi-ove to be a
success in every regard is unusually
bright, and the men in charge have
every reason to believe that the
present cotillon season will have an
eventful and auspicious opening.
There is to be a woman's football game between -Minnesota and
Wisconsin. Rooters will be present
from both sides, and between halves
both players and rooters will partake of a feast furnished by the
Minnesota co-eds.

Y. M. C. A. SOCIAL SERVICE

THE UNIVERSITY GLEE CLUB

The University Young Men's
Christian Association is now offering to students an opportunity for
a new kind of voluntary work.
Students are needed to take charge
of the boys' work at the Lawrence
House and the Locust Point Mission. This work consists of teaching the boys athletic games and
giving them, in connection with
these games, physical training. Besides, the boys are to be taught a
brief elementary course in civics.
Hence it is obvious that students
taking up this work will find that
the instruction resolves itself into
several different branches, which
should make it all the more interesting and instructive.
Secretary Sutton will be glad to
give fuller particulars to those Mr
would like to volunteer in this form
of social service.
The Association also needs men
to act as ushers at the big Young
Men's Christian Association meetings, which will be held on eight or
nine consecutive Sundays at Ford's
Theatre. Seven students have already volunteered their services as
ushers at these meetings. Several
more are still needed.
As announced recently in TM,
NEWS-LETTER, Mr. A. C. Harte, the
secretary of the Y. M. C. A. work
among the natives of India, will deliver an address today (Monday)
under the auspices of the Association. Mr. Harte, who was one of
the big speakers at the convention
of the Student Volunteer Movement
held at Kansas City last January,
spoke Sunday at a meeting at
Ford's and has prolonged his stay
here in order to accommodate the
University Association. In view of
this, the Association is striving to
have as many students as possible
attend this meeting.
Dr. Hogue will lead the chapel
services this week.

Although it was decided at the
beginning of the season by the
Board of Managers that no Christmas trip would be taken by the
Musical Clubs this year, an offer is
being considered which may result
in the making of arrangements for
a trip to Western Maryland during
the coming holidays, and, pending
the action of the Board, the Glee
and Instrumental Clubs are working overtime in order to be ready
in the event that such a trip is
scheduled.
One of the chief objections to a
Christmas trip is that the men do
not have time to adequately prepare
themselves to represent Johns Hopkins at any out-of-town concerts so
early in the season, and in order to
overcome this obstacle leaders of
the Clubs are calling extra rehearsals and are redoubling their
efforts to get their respective teams
in condition to give a "corking
good concert" at whatever places
engagements are obtained.
Some trouble is being experienced by the Glee Club on account
of a lack of competent candidates
for positions as first tenors and
first basses. It hardly seems possible that in a university of the size
of Johns Hopkins there should be
such a small number of men who
have good tenor voices; and if there
is in either the graduate or undergraduate departments any man who
has a tenor voice of any quality and
who has not yet come out for the
Glee Club he will confer a great
favor on the leader if he will make
a distinct effort to be on hand at the
next rehearsal—he is needed!
The leader of the Glee Club has
selected a quartet, which is now at
work preparing several good songs;
two or three clever "stunts" are being worked out, and if two or three
good tenors show up in the next

Although St. John's won the
closing battle of the 'Varsity's football season on Thanksgiving Day,
34 to 13, Johns Hopkins had the
honor of having the individual star
of the game on its side.
Bob Hoffman, '18, was without
doubt the best player of the twentytwo men on the field, and it was
mainly due to his work that Hopkins was able to score the two
touchdowns that gave it some consolation in defeat. Bob did his
plunging without interference of a
very marked character, and he
made substantial gains. He ran
back five punts almost to mid-field,
and throughout the game made
tackles that none of his team mates
could equal. He was not only the
best player on the Hopkins side,
but outshone all of his opponents.
If Hopkins had dormitories and a
very marked "college spirit," Bob
Hoffman would be a hero today.
• That the 'Varsity did as well as
to score two touchdowns and hold
the more experienced and better
trained St. John's team to 33 points
was viewed with satisfaction by
those who were in close touch with
the condition of the team. Many
shifts in the line-up throughout the
season, the absence of good coaching in the three days preceding the
game and the costly slump taken
the week before augured a poorer
showing than was made. Some
thought St. John's would roll up
sixty points, and one publicist predicted a rout.
But Hopkins was not beaten
worse than Yale was by Harvard;
Army had 20 points more than
Navy. and St. John's had 21 more
points than Hopkins. In comparison with the big games of the
season, the result was not so humiliating.
And while apologies are being
made, it may be well to recall the
difficulties that the team experienced this )!ear in building up its
machine. Several men who held
'Varsity positions early in the
schedule were forced to retire in
the middle of the season, and their
loss caused a serious setback to
the work of the team as a whole.
New men had to be developed, and
radical shifts were made in the
line-up. Practices this season, too,
were not of sufficient length to give
the men proper training. There
was hardly a day on which the
entire first team was able to report before six o'clock, and consequently all work had to be done
under arc lights.

DR. BUTLER TELLS OF SARDIS
Princeton Professor, Who Directed the
Excavations at Old City in Asia
Minor, Explains His Finds.

Dr. Howard Crosby Butler, professor of Architecture at Princeton
University and director of the
American excavations at Sardis,
gave an interesting illustrated lecture last Monday evening before
the Baltimore Section of the Archeological Institute on "American Excavations at Sardis." After a few
introductory remarks by Dr. David
M. Robinson, of the University, Dr.
Butler outlined briefly the geography and history of the city of
Croesus.
On one of the trade routes to the
East, the city grew in wealth; here
money was first coined and here
flourished one of the great centers
of ancient times. Finally in the year
17, of our era, the city was destroyed
by earthquake and the great hill of
clay, which formed its acropolis,
was strewn over the ruins of the
city.
When excavating work was begun several years ago, only the tops
of two columns protruded above the
surface. Today the whole foundation of the temple is laid bare to the
eye, with its magnificent portico of
Ionic columns, 50 to 60 feet high
and 7 feet in diameter at the base.
Besides this Grecian temple of the
fourth century B. C., a Roman
building and a Christian church
have also been unearthed. The difficulties of the work, however, are
greatly increased, since the level 01
excavation is almost 50 feet below
the surface and every bit of dirt
must be carried out and dumped.
Not only have levels of the Roman, Hellenistic, Lydian and Mycerrean periods been disclosed, but
pottery has also been found at the
lowest level of the Minoan Age,
dating back to the second millenium
before Christ. Although the discoveries in sculpture are not quite
so plentiful, some fine examples
have been unearthed. Finally, the
party has laid bare several inscriptions of value, one being the first
authentic Lydian inscription in existence; another, in Greek, telling
of a temple to Zeus, has furnished
the inspiration and object toward
which future .work at Sardis will be
directed.

Dr. Goodnow Goes to Pittsburgh.

President Goodnow left Baltimore last Tuesday on a trip to Pittsburgh, where he was the guest of
the president of the Carnegie Institute for the Founder's Day exercises. Founder's Day, more generally known as Carnegie Day, is
celebrated at Carnegie Institute on
November 25 each year to commemorate the founding of the Institute by Andrew Carnegie.
The exercises are always featured
by the presence of distinguished
speakers and visitors from all parts
of the country and Dr. Goodnow
had the honor of being chief speaker of the day. He returned to this
city immediately upon the conclusion of the exercises.
Origins of Cheer and Hurrah.

At a time when all the colleges
of America are organized into bands
of rooters it is interesting to trace
the derivation of the words and customs of cheering. The word cheer
meant'originally face or expression,
and is said to have come through
the Old French into Middle English from the Latin coral, meaning
head. Next "cheer" was used in
connection with hospitality and entertainment, and hence in connection with food and drink—"good
cheer." The sense of a shout of
encouragement or applause is a late
use.
The sound of hurrah is found in
various forms in German, Scandanavian, Russian and French. The
English hurrah was preceded by
inizza, stated to be a sailor's word
and generally connected with heeze,
to hoist.
The custom of cheering is a development of the primitive war-cry.
Probably the oldest example of a
cheer in the United States was the
ode given to George Washington:
Who
First
First
First

was George Washington?
in war,
in peace,
in the hearts of his countrymen.

Followed by a stamping on the
floor in the same rhythm.
English crowds were first familiarized with regular cheering at
games in 1o07, when the New Zealand football team used a sort of
war-cry adopted from the Maoris.
The oldest college yells of America
are those of the New England colleges.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 3D, 1914.

HOW THE EUROPEAN WAR IS AFFECTING OXFORD
Carl J. Weber,'14, Rhodes Scholar, in a Special Article for The
News-Letter, Says British Students Are Glad to Exchange
Their Academic Robes for Military Costumes.
College Buildings Used as Hospitals.
Imagine Hopkins with less than
one hundred undergraduates, no
athletic games, no gymnasium, no
glee club, no cotillons, no NENNTsLETTER, the Hullabaloo filled with
obituaries and epitaphs, McCoy
Hall a hospital, with a train of ambulances from it to Union Station;
lectures attended by a handful of
students, many of them in military
uniform — imagine this, and you
have a picture of how war may affect a college or a university. This
is Oxford today.
Needless to say, the German universities also are practically deserted. The natives are busy elsewhere, students from hostile countries are imprisoned and American
students have been sent out of Germany. Late in September a special train left that country carrying
practically all the American students who had been patiently waiting there for the end of the war.
Many of these students are now in
Oxford.
French universities are in the
same condition. The French students are away at the front, and
Americans who had intended to
study at the Sorbonne or at Grenoble or elsewhere have turned
aside and are at present in Oxford.
The Belgian universities are, of
course, idle, and hundreds of Belgian students are gathered at the
English educational centers, exchanging instruction in French .foi
opportunities to study English.
The professors of the university
at Louvain and other institutions in
Belgium which have been closed because of the war are without positions. They can find none here in
England, for there are now already too many instructors for the
students. I understand that American universities and colleges are
trying to use these men. Certainly
some of them are authorities and
would make valuable additions to
the staffs of the United States colleges which secure their services.
Many of these professors and
students have flocked to Oxford
College, which, in spite of the war,
is continuing, though at a rather
moderate gait. Very few British
students remain, and I have met
American students from Poland,
Belgium, Bohemia, Russia and Germany who have come to take their
places. Oxford, having lost its native men, is recruiting new students
from among the numbers who have
fled the Continental educational
centers.
The war has made profound
changes here at Oxford. Those
who have been here in normal times
say that they can hardly recognize
it as the same place. Everything
seems dead and insipid. Instead of
3,000 students, there are at present
only about 1,200 scattered among

the twenty-two colleges. Some colleges have suffered more than
others, but the average proportion
is that slightly less than half of the
usual number are "up," i. e., in
residence.
Queen's College is rather above
the average. Here there are usually about 175 students; of these, 85
have joined the army-15 of them
"freshers." About five also of the
college servants have enlisted. Of
the 1,200 students yet remaining in
Oxford, about 700 have joined the
local officers' training corps and are
drilling daily. There is one great
advantage in this: the military uniform allows them to dispense with
their caps and gowns. This body
of students expect commissions
next spring or early in the summer,
so that if the war continues there
will be left at Oxford only about
500 men. These will be largely the
lame, the halt, the blind—and the
American.
This paucity of students has had
numerous results. Athletics have
practically disappeared. All intercollegiate games have been abandoned and many an athletic field is
lying absolutely idle. There are a
few boats on the river, but there
will be no races; a few men go out
to practice soccer or "Rugger," but
they always have to advertise to get
a team together. Tennis is about
the only sport that has not been
injured.
The Concert Society, Debating,
Political and other social clubs have
all abandoned their usual programs
and are merely trying to remain in
existence until the war is over. The
Oxford Union Society, the society
here, is said to be going rapidly into debt every day. The only club
not seriously affected by the war
is the American Club. Several
weeks ago it debated the question:
"That the United States should declare war against Germany."
In many other ways the war is
making itself felt here. The Examination Schools have been turned
into a hospital, with a big Red
Cross flag over it to attract Zeppelins. One day a train of wounded
soldiers arrives and the next the
students are solicited for subscriptions to buy the wounded men
newspapers, cigarettes and matches.
College quads are the scenes of student drills and at odd hours during
the day a company or two will
march down the street singing some
classic American "rag." The college gates are closed an hour earlier
than usual in the evening, in order
to give the military students more
sleep. Special services are held in
the college chapels and there is very
little of that liveliness and spirit in
the air that one usually associates
with the idea of college life.

ing," and set to work to make preparations for defeating St. John's
next year. If Hopkins is going to
play football, it must play football
well. It will never be able to do
this, however, until all elements
tending to make a successful team
work sympathetically together.
The time is coming when there
will be dormitories at Homewood,
and then the Black and Blue will
reach its summit of football efficiency. There will be plenty of
spirit, the football men will be regarded as college gods (as they
should be) and, above all, there
will be a systematic schedule of
hours .for practice.
But until this ideal condition is
reached, there must be a good football organization made right here
under conditions as they now exist.
There must be more spirit in the
undergraduate body; there must be
a different system of coaching;
there must be a better scrub team;
there must be a way to practice before six o'clock, and there must be
an understanding with the faculty.
In other words, a more general interest must be taken in matters of
football.
Least complaint is to be made in
the matter of undergraduate spirit.
We have said in this place before
that Cheer Leader Jack DeWitt
managed his work in excellent style.
The yelling was good all season.
But, like everything else, it can be
bettered.
The matter of coaching is something that we should not attempt
to criticize in this column. Suffice
it to say, however, that Hopkins
needs an instructor in football
rather than a professor. A high
school class in Latin would perhaps
learn little from Professor Gildersleeve. And, likewise, the football
team needs a teacher of fundamentals.
But the present coaching system
is not wholly to blame for the poor
season. Hopkins should have a
better scrub team against which to
practice. This season's second team
was a light one, and a workout
against it afforded very little training. The 'Varsity pushed it up and
down field at will, wasting time and
making life miserable for the
scrubs.
The greatest difficulty is the time
of practice. No team can make
much headway after five hours of
practice a week, and this at night
in the glare of arc lights. Some
of the State teams whose players
live in dormitories overlooking the
gridirons had practices twice daily.
The men dressed in their togs before breakfast and were put through
a signal drill. They again took
the field after classes were over in
the afternoon, sometimes at three
o'clock, for the second workout of
the day. They received three hours
of instruction under coaches who
were always with the men infusing
spirit at the same time they were
teaching football. Football was the
avocation: study, the vocation. The
game was constantly in mind, but

The Football Situation.

The defeat administered by St.
John's on Thanksgiving afternoon
was not so bad after all. True,
there was a margin of 21 points,
but when the score is compared
with the results of other big games
of the season, Hopkins should not
feel that its colors have been
dragged in the dirt.
As our first-page account of the
game says, the outcome of the
battle was even better than those
familiar with the team and its condition had thought. The 'Varsity
has worked this season under difficulties which it was unable to
master, but which it met in a very
creditable manner.
It is not the proper thing, then,
that we should sit down and mourn.
We should recall all those Sprichworten such as "Pain makes gain,"
"Success• is often born in defeat,"
and "Every cloud has a silver lin-

not at the expense of college work.
Hopkins must have more time for
practice. Just how to get this time
is the great problem that will confront the men who manage football
affairs.
And matters would certainly be
made much smoother if the football management could work out its
problems in conference with the
faculty. There seems to be some
opposition. We should not have
this keep up. Since it appears that
Hopkins must have football, it must
be good football. To get good football the faculty and management
must arrive at some definite and
mutually satisfactory arrangement
whereby each will know the other's
attitude. It makes it very embarrassing and disagreeable for a man
to be begged to play by his colleagues and be prohibited by his
instructors. The man suffers and
the team suffers. The opposition
to football should be crystallized
into a rule if a majority of the
faculty approves, and this rule
should be observed. And when an
arrangement of this character is
made, the team should have the
solid support of the professors and
instructors.
And now is the proper time to
thrash out these matters of importance to the welfare of football at
Hopkins. The season just past has
shown that there are many difficulties to be surmounted before a
really good team can be put on the
field. Hopkins had the men for an
excellent team, but they could not
be developed. The captain, manager and graduate manager best
know why they were not developed.
Let them sum up their observations
and present them to the football
committee, advisers and faculty.
With these men showing a desire
for betterment and a true Hopkins
spirit, nothing but good could result. TheS, can lay plans for a new
and better football organization
next year, and then after the St.
John's game, the Annapolis rooters
will not have the inspiration to do
their serpentine dance on Homewood Field.

HOW THE WAR IS AFFECTING OXFORD
(Continued from page 3)

Even American students here are
affected by the war. There is not
the usual schedule of lectures, for
there are not enough men to attend.
Many of the great lecturers have
temporarily abandoned their work.
So close to London, there is a tenseness prevalent which compels a
close study of what is going on in
naval and military circles, and as
everybody is profoundly interested
in these, study is partially affected.
I do not believe that war is popular with the students. I do not
say, however, that they are ignoring the appeals for voluntary service. The college men are among
the first to enlist, giving up everything that they might serve their
country in its time of strife. But
they have not that military spirit
which marks the chief opponent
and they would rather be studying
than fighting; not rather fighting
than studying, the spirit in Germany.
The American Club here, a club
composed of students from all over
the Eastern Hemisphere, has decided to omit its usual Thanksgiving
Dinner this year, because it was
feared the English might think that
we were trying to celebrate the
Fourth of July while they were at
war. Of course, such a belief
would not be current among the
people who were familiar with the
club, but it was thought that perhaps a report of the affair would
be misunderstood by people not living at Oxford. When we think of
the good old-fashioned dinner we
have missed, we get a most practical example of the fact that "war
is hell."

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Two students in the University
of Washington have undertaken the
construction of what will be the
largest electrical transformer on
the Pacific Coast, as a thesis for a
degree in engineering. They are
Leo Dashley and John Dodds, both
Seattle men.
The transformer, which will be
ready for use in the spring, will be
surpassed in size by but two or
three in the entire country, the
larger ones being in testing laboratories of big electrical companies. The apparatus is to be set
up in the engineering building for
research work and the testing of
.insulating materials. It will be
seven feet high, four feet wide and
two feet thick; will contain 303
pounds of wire; throw a spark
twenty inches and will step up the
voltage from 220 to 220,000 volts.
* * *
Fifty freshmen of the University
of Colorado have been haled before the Student Commission for
violation of the associated student
rules, which provide that no firstyear man shall appear on the campus wearing any headgear other
than the official postage stamp cap
with the green button. The Commission is given power to punish
all offenders of this rule.
* * * •
A whist contest between the faculty and the seniors of Kansas University is being planned by the
Student Union.
According to the papers that have
been turned in to the White Cross
Committee, more than ',coo students and members of the faculty
have contributed to the fund for
the relief of the Belgians. Besides
these funds, much clothing is also
being collected for the aid of the
European sufferers.
* * *
The chickens belonging to the
University of Missouri have been
vaccinated to prevent roup. These
chickens are prize birds of the
Poultry Department.
* * *
A new department of wireless
telegraphy has been instituted at
Tulane University. The offices of
the department were at first in the
rooms of two of the students, but
have been recently moved to the
engineering building. At first the
students used their bedsprings for
receiving wires and operated with
electric light switches.
* * *
. .
At the University of Missouri
there has been a straw vote taken
so as to ascertain who were in favor of equal suffrage. Of the five
hundred men that voted, 298 were
in favor of giving the women the
vote.

FOUR INJURED MEN DOING WELL
Bob Layfield Is Stronger—Capt. Paul
Wilkinson, Claude Uhler, and Ed
Pfitsch Have Broken Bones.

There was no change in the general condition of Bob Layfield last
week, but he is much stronger than
he has been at any time since his
back was broken in the Lehigh game
a month ago. The complete paralysis still exists, but Bob is brighter than he has ever been since the
accident.
A letter received from the Maryland Club of Lehigh Alumni by
the Athletic Association last week
is as follows:
To the Athletic Committee
of Johns Hopkins University:
The Lehigh Club of Maryland desires
me to assure you of the deep regret of
its members at the terrible injury sustained by one of the Johns Hopkins
team—Robert Layfield—in the recent
Johns Hopkins-Lehigh football game.
Their sincere sympathy rests with
Mr. Layfield and his family, and they
earnestly hope that his splendid fight
against odds may result in the victory
he so nobly deserves—a complete and
speedy recovery.
Very truly yours,
W. HOWARD CORDREY,Secretary,
Lehigh Club of Maryland.

There were two injuries received
in the St. John's game, but neither
was of a serious nature. Captain
Wilkinson's nose was broken in a
mass play, but it has been set very
skillfully, and the break is not
noticeable.
In the third quarter, Edgar
Pfitsch's left arm was broken just
above the wrist, in less than a minute after he had gone into the play.
He was sent in to substitute for
Gorman. It was the fourth down
with two yards to go. Coach Cates
sent Pfitsch in, and a line play with
him to carry was called. Pfitsch
made the distance with a yard to
spare, but he could not get up. He
was carried from the field. Dr.
Abercrombie and Dr. Stone set the
bone temporarily, and Pfitsch was
sent to his home. He went to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital Friday
morning, and the arm was put in
a cast.
The distance he covered in the
one play in which he carried the
ball made one of the two Hopkins
touchdowns possible. Pfitsch will
be able to attend his classes without losing much time.
The fouFth accident of the season
was that received by Halfback
Claude Uhler in the Western Maryland game. Uhler's ankle bones
were fractured in a mass play, and
he was taken from the game. He
did not believe the injury a serious
one at first, and it was treated as
an ordinary sprain. He went to
the Johns Hopkins Hospital Monday, and an X-ray photograph revealed several broken bones in the
instep. They were set, and a cast
was placed around the left foot.
Uhler goes about on crutches, and
was leaning on the arms of a
couple of lady friends at Saturday's
game. He says that his injury is
not so bad after all.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 30, 1914.

'VARSITY LOSES TO ST. JOHN'S

FIRST COTILLON FRIDAY NIGHT
The Opening Dance Will Continue Until
12.30 A.M. Louie's Orchestra to
Begin Playing at 8.30 P.M.

The large percentage of the student body who believe, as does a
Baltimore instructor not unknown
to fame, that "dancing is a fine art,"
will be afforded an unusually attractive opportunity to exercise the
"light fantastic toe," when the
sweet seductive notes from Louie
Fisher's orchestra usher in the first
cotillon of the season Friday night.
Eight-thirty has been set is the
time for the opening of festivities,
which, in accordance with a special
dispensation from the Powers that
Be, will continue until thirty minutes of Saturday morning have
flown by. How this arrangement
.will please the numerous janitors
and gentlemen-in-waiting has not
as. yet been ascertained, but all
other parties intimately concerned
have expressed their heart-felt approval. It was the desire of the
Cotillon Board that one o'clock
might be the closing hour, but half
a loaf is so decidedly better than
none, that the gaining of an extra
half-hour is regarded as a conquest
of no mean importance.
The cotillon will consist of twenty
dances, of which the tenth and
eleventh will be supper dances.
Every fourth dance, throughout the
evening, will be a waltz, in order
that the few unfortunates who
have not yet entirely mastered the
mysteries of the elusive fox-trot
may not feel utterly abandoned and
apart. Those who by dint of exceeding great effort have reached
this pinnacle of accomplishment,
however, will by no means be forgotten, and the best efforts of
Louie's orchestra will be devoted to
their entertainment and delight.
The veteran leader in many a
hard-fought cotillon has promised
to procure the very latest and best
dance music from New York to
grace this gala occasion, and the
persuasive powers of his melodious
band of satellites are too well
known to require comment. All
things considered, the, prospect for
an affair that will pi-ove to be a
success in every regard is unusually
bright, and the men in charge have
every reason to believe that the
present cotillon season will have an
eventful and auspicious opening.
There is to be a woman's football game between -Minnesota and
Wisconsin. Rooters will be present
from both sides, and between halves
both players and rooters will partake of a feast furnished by the
Minnesota co-eds.

Y. M. C. A. SOCIAL SERVICE

THE UNIVERSITY GLEE CLUB

The University Young Men's
Christian Association is now offering to students an opportunity for
a new kind of voluntary work.
Students are needed to take charge
of the boys' work at the Lawrence
House and the Locust Point Mission. This work consists of teaching the boys athletic games and
giving them, in connection with
these games, physical training. Besides, the boys are to be taught a
brief elementary course in civics.
Hence it is obvious that students
taking up this work will find that
the instruction resolves itself into
several different branches, which
should make it all the more interesting and instructive.
Secretary Sutton will be glad to
give fuller particulars to those Mr
would like to volunteer in this form
of social service.
The Association also needs men
to act as ushers at the big Young
Men's Christian Association meetings, which will be held on eight or
nine consecutive Sundays at Ford's
Theatre. Seven students have already volunteered their services as
ushers at these meetings. Several
more are still needed.
As announced recently in TM,
NEWS-LETTER, Mr. A. C. Harte, the
secretary of the Y. M. C. A. work
among the natives of India, will deliver an address today (Monday)
under the auspices of the Association. Mr. Harte, who was one of
the big speakers at the convention
of the Student Volunteer Movement
held at Kansas City last January,
spoke Sunday at a meeting at
Ford's and has prolonged his stay
here in order to accommodate the
University Association. In view of
this, the Association is striving to
have as many students as possible
attend this meeting.
Dr. Hogue will lead the chapel
services this week.

Although it was decided at the
beginning of the season by the
Board of Managers that no Christmas trip would be taken by the
Musical Clubs this year, an offer is
being considered which may result
in the making of arrangements for
a trip to Western Maryland during
the coming holidays, and, pending
the action of the Board, the Glee
and Instrumental Clubs are working overtime in order to be ready
in the event that such a trip is
scheduled.
One of the chief objections to a
Christmas trip is that the men do
not have time to adequately prepare
themselves to represent Johns Hopkins at any out-of-town concerts so
early in the season, and in order to
overcome this obstacle leaders of
the Clubs are calling extra rehearsals and are redoubling their
efforts to get their respective teams
in condition to give a "corking
good concert" at whatever places
engagements are obtained.
Some trouble is being experienced by the Glee Club on account
of a lack of competent candidates
for positions as first tenors and
first basses. It hardly seems possible that in a university of the size
of Johns Hopkins there should be
such a small number of men who
have good tenor voices; and if there
is in either the graduate or undergraduate departments any man who
has a tenor voice of any quality and
who has not yet come out for the
Glee Club he will confer a great
favor on the leader if he will make
a distinct effort to be on hand at the
next rehearsal—he is needed!
The leader of the Glee Club has
selected a quartet, which is now at
work preparing several good songs;
two or three clever "stunts" are being worked out, and if two or three
good tenors show up in the next

Although St. John's won the
closing battle of the 'Varsity's football season on Thanksgiving Day,
34 to 13, Johns Hopkins had the
honor of having the individual star
of the game on its side.
Bob Hoffman, '18, was without
doubt the best player of the twentytwo men on the field, and it was
mainly due to his work that Hopkins was able to score the two
touchdowns that gave it some consolation in defeat. Bob did his
plunging without interference of a
very marked character, and he
made substantial gains. He ran
back five punts almost to mid-field,
and throughout the game made
tackles that none of his team mates
could equal. He was not only the
best player on the Hopkins side,
but outshone all of his opponents.
If Hopkins had dormitories and a
very marked "college spirit," Bob
Hoffman would be a hero today.
• That the 'Varsity did as well as
to score two touchdowns and hold
the more experienced and better
trained St. John's team to 33 points
was viewed with satisfaction by
those who were in close touch with
the condition of the team. Many
shifts in the line-up throughout the
season, the absence of good coaching in the three days preceding the
game and the costly slump taken
the week before augured a poorer
showing than was made. Some
thought St. John's would roll up
sixty points, and one publicist predicted a rout.
But Hopkins was not beaten
worse than Yale was by Harvard;
Army had 20 points more than
Navy. and St. John's had 21 more
points than Hopkins. In comparison with the big games of the
season, the result was not so humiliating.
And while apologies are being
made, it may be well to recall the
difficulties that the team experienced this )!ear in building up its
machine. Several men who held
'Varsity positions early in the
schedule were forced to retire in
the middle of the season, and their
loss caused a serious setback to
the work of the team as a whole.
New men had to be developed, and
radical shifts were made in the
line-up. Practices this season, too,
were not of sufficient length to give
the men proper training. There
was hardly a day on which the
entire first team was able to report before six o'clock, and consequently all work had to be done
under arc lights.

DR. BUTLER TELLS OF SARDIS
Princeton Professor, Who Directed the
Excavations at Old City in Asia
Minor, Explains His Finds.

Dr. Howard Crosby Butler, professor of Architecture at Princeton
University and director of the
American excavations at Sardis,
gave an interesting illustrated lecture last Monday evening before
the Baltimore Section of the Archeological Institute on "American Excavations at Sardis." After a few
introductory remarks by Dr. David
M. Robinson, of the University, Dr.
Butler outlined briefly the geography and history of the city of
Croesus.
On one of the trade routes to the
East, the city grew in wealth; here
money was first coined and here
flourished one of the great centers
of ancient times. Finally in the year
17, of our era, the city was destroyed
by earthquake and the great hill of
clay, which formed its acropolis,
was strewn over the ruins of the
city.
When excavating work was begun several years ago, only the tops
of two columns protruded above the
surface. Today the whole foundation of the temple is laid bare to the
eye, with its magnificent portico of
Ionic columns, 50 to 60 feet high
and 7 feet in diameter at the base.
Besides this Grecian temple of the
fourth century B. C., a Roman
building and a Christian church
have also been unearthed. The difficulties of the work, however, are
greatly increased, since the level 01
excavation is almost 50 feet below
the surface and every bit of dirt
must be carried out and dumped.
Not only have levels of the Roman, Hellenistic, Lydian and Mycerrean periods been disclosed, but
pottery has also been found at the
lowest level of the Minoan Age,
dating back to the second millenium
before Christ. Although the discoveries in sculpture are not quite
so plentiful, some fine examples
have been unearthed. Finally, the
party has laid bare several inscriptions of value, one being the first
authentic Lydian inscription in existence; another, in Greek, telling
of a temple to Zeus, has furnished
the inspiration and object toward
which future .work at Sardis will be
directed.

Dr. Goodnow Goes to Pittsburgh.

President Goodnow left Baltimore last Tuesday on a trip to Pittsburgh, where he was the guest of
the president of the Carnegie Institute for the Founder's Day exercises. Founder's Day, more generally known as Carnegie Day, is
celebrated at Carnegie Institute on
November 25 each year to commemorate the founding of the Institute by Andrew Carnegie.
The exercises are always featured
by the presence of distinguished
speakers and visitors from all parts
of the country and Dr. Goodnow
had the honor of being chief speaker of the day. He returned to this
city immediately upon the conclusion of the exercises.
Origins of Cheer and Hurrah.

At a time when all the colleges
of America are organized into bands
of rooters it is interesting to trace
the derivation of the words and customs of cheering. The word cheer
meant'originally face or expression,
and is said to have come through
the Old French into Middle English from the Latin coral, meaning
head. Next "cheer" was used in
connection with hospitality and entertainment, and hence in connection with food and drink—"good
cheer." The sense of a shout of
encouragement or applause is a late
use.
The sound of hurrah is found in
various forms in German, Scandanavian, Russian and French. The
English hurrah was preceded by
inizza, stated to be a sailor's word
and generally connected with heeze,
to hoist.
The custom of cheering is a development of the primitive war-cry.
Probably the oldest example of a
cheer in the United States was the
ode given to George Washington:
Who
First
First
First

was George Washington?
in war,
in peace,
in the hearts of his countrymen.

Followed by a stamping on the
floor in the same rhythm.
English crowds were first familiarized with regular cheering at
games in 1o07, when the New Zealand football team used a sort of
war-cry adopted from the Maoris.
The oldest college yells of America
are those of the New England colleges.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 3D, 1914.

HOW THE EUROPEAN WAR IS AFFECTING OXFORD
Carl J. Weber,'14, Rhodes Scholar, in a Special Article for The
News-Letter, Says British Students Are Glad to Exchange
Their Academic Robes for Military Costumes.
College Buildings Used as Hospitals.
Imagine Hopkins with less than
one hundred undergraduates, no
athletic games, no gymnasium, no
glee club, no cotillons, no NENNTsLETTER, the Hullabaloo filled with
obituaries and epitaphs, McCoy
Hall a hospital, with a train of ambulances from it to Union Station;
lectures attended by a handful of
students, many of them in military
uniform — imagine this, and you
have a picture of how war may affect a college or a university. This
is Oxford today.
Needless to say, the German universities also are practically deserted. The natives are busy elsewhere, students from hostile countries are imprisoned and American
students have been sent out of Germany. Late in September a special train left that country carrying
practically all the American students who had been patiently waiting there for the end of the war.
Many of these students are now in
Oxford.
French universities are in the
same condition. The French students are away at the front, and
Americans who had intended to
study at the Sorbonne or at Grenoble or elsewhere have turned
aside and are at present in Oxford.
The Belgian universities are, of
course, idle, and hundreds of Belgian students are gathered at the
English educational centers, exchanging instruction in French .foi
opportunities to study English.
The professors of the university
at Louvain and other institutions in
Belgium which have been closed because of the war are without positions. They can find none here in
England, for there are now already too many instructors for the
students. I understand that American universities and colleges are
trying to use these men. Certainly
some of them are authorities and
would make valuable additions to
the staffs of the United States colleges which secure their services.
Many of these professors and
students have flocked to Oxford
College, which, in spite of the war,
is continuing, though at a rather
moderate gait. Very few British
students remain, and I have met
American students from Poland,
Belgium, Bohemia, Russia and Germany who have come to take their
places. Oxford, having lost its native men, is recruiting new students
from among the numbers who have
fled the Continental educational
centers.
The war has made profound
changes here at Oxford. Those
who have been here in normal times
say that they can hardly recognize
it as the same place. Everything
seems dead and insipid. Instead of
3,000 students, there are at present
only about 1,200 scattered among

the twenty-two colleges. Some colleges have suffered more than
others, but the average proportion
is that slightly less than half of the
usual number are "up," i. e., in
residence.
Queen's College is rather above
the average. Here there are usually about 175 students; of these, 85
have joined the army-15 of them
"freshers." About five also of the
college servants have enlisted. Of
the 1,200 students yet remaining in
Oxford, about 700 have joined the
local officers' training corps and are
drilling daily. There is one great
advantage in this: the military uniform allows them to dispense with
their caps and gowns. This body
of students expect commissions
next spring or early in the summer,
so that if the war continues there
will be left at Oxford only about
500 men. These will be largely the
lame, the halt, the blind—and the
American.
This paucity of students has had
numerous results. Athletics have
practically disappeared. All intercollegiate games have been abandoned and many an athletic field is
lying absolutely idle. There are a
few boats on the river, but there
will be no races; a few men go out
to practice soccer or "Rugger," but
they always have to advertise to get
a team together. Tennis is about
the only sport that has not been
injured.
The Concert Society, Debating,
Political and other social clubs have
all abandoned their usual programs
and are merely trying to remain in
existence until the war is over. The
Oxford Union Society, the society
here, is said to be going rapidly into debt every day. The only club
not seriously affected by the war
is the American Club. Several
weeks ago it debated the question:
"That the United States should declare war against Germany."
In many other ways the war is
making itself felt here. The Examination Schools have been turned
into a hospital, with a big Red
Cross flag over it to attract Zeppelins. One day a train of wounded
soldiers arrives and the next the
students are solicited for subscriptions to buy the wounded men
newspapers, cigarettes and matches.
College quads are the scenes of student drills and at odd hours during
the day a company or two will
march down the street singing some
classic American "rag." The college gates are closed an hour earlier
than usual in the evening, in order
to give the military students more
sleep. Special services are held in
the college chapels and there is very
little of that liveliness and spirit in
the air that one usually associates
with the idea of college life.
(Continued on page 4, col. 4)

next year. If Hopkins is going to
play football, it must play football
well. It will never be able to do
this, however, until all elements
tending to make a successful team
work sympathetically together.
The time is coming when there
will be dormitories at Homewood,
and then the Black and Blue will
reach its summit of football efficiency. There will be plenty of
spirit, the football men will be regarded as college gods (as they
should be) and, above all, there
will be a systematic schedule of
hours .for practice.
But until this ideal condition is
reached, there must be a good football organization made right here
under conditions as they now exist.
There must be more spirit in the
undergraduate body; there must be
a different system of coaching;
there must be a better scrub team;
there must be a way to practice before six o'clock, and there must be
an understanding with the faculty.
In other words, a more general interest must be taken in matters of
football.
Least complaint is to be made in
the matter of undergraduate spirit.
We have said in this place before
that Cheer Leader Jack DeWitt
managed his work in excellent style.
The yelling was good all season.
But, like everything else, it can be
bettered.
The matter of coaching is something that we should not attempt
to criticize in this column. Suffice
it to say, however, that Hopkins
needs an instructor in football
rather than a professor. A high
school class in Latin would perhaps
learn little from Professor Gildersleeve. And, likewise, the football
team needs a teacher of fundamentals.
But the present coaching system
is not wholly to blame for the poor
season. Hopkins should have a
better scrub team against which to
practice. This season's second team
was a light one, and a workout
against it afforded very little training. The 'Varsity pushed it up and
down field at will, wasting time and
making life miserable for the
scrubs.
The greatest difficulty is the time
of practice. No team can make
much headway after five hours of
practice a week, and this at night
in the glare of arc lights. Some
of the State teams whose players
live in dormitories overlooking the
gridirons had practices twice daily.
The men dressed in their togs before breakfast and were put through
a signal drill. They again took
the field after classes were over in
the afternoon, sometimes at three
o'clock, for the second workout of
the day. They received three hours
of instruction under coaches who
were always with the men infusing
spirit at the same time they were
teaching football. Football was the
avocation: study, the vocation. The
game was constantly in mind, but

The Football Situation.

The defeat administered by St.
John's on Thanksgiving afternoon
was not so bad after all. True,
there was a margin of 21 points,
but when the score is compared
with the results of other big games
of the season, Hopkins should not
feel that its colors have been
dragged in the dirt.
As our first-page account of the
game says, the outcome of the
battle was even better than those
familiar with the team and its condition had thought. The 'Varsity
has worked this season under difficulties which it was unable to
master, but which it met in a very
creditable manner.
It is not the proper thing, then,
that we should sit down and mourn.
We should recall all those Sprichworten such as "Pain makes gain,"
"Success• is often born in defeat,"
and "Every cloud has a silver lin-

not at the expense of college work.
Hopkins must have more time for
practice. Just how to get this time
is the great problem that will confront the men who manage football
affairs.
And matters would certainly be
made much smoother if the football management could work out its
problems in conference with the
faculty. There seems to be some
opposition. We should not have
this keep up. Since it appears that
Hopkins must have football, it must
be good football. To get good football the faculty and management
must arrive at some definite and
mutually satisfactory arrangement
whereby each will know the other's
attitude. It makes it very embarrassing and disagreeable for a man
to be begged to play by his colleagues and be prohibited by his
instructors. The man suffers and
the team suffers. The opposition
to football should be crystallized
into a rule if a majority of the
faculty approves, and this rule
should be observed. And when an
arrangement of this character is
made, the team should have the
solid support of the professors and
instructors.
And now is the proper time to
thrash out these matters of importance to the welfare of football at
Hopkins. The season just past has
shown that there are many difficulties to be surmounted before a
really good team can be put on the
field. Hopkins had the men for an
excellent team, but they could not
be developed. The captain, manager and graduate manager best
know why they were not developed.
Let them sum up their observations
and present them to the football
committee, advisers and faculty.
With these men showing a desire
for betterment and a true Hopkins
spirit, nothing but good could result. TheS, can lay plans for a new
and better football organization
next year, and then after the St.
John's game, the Annapolis rooters
will not have the inspiration to do
their serpentine dance on Homewood Field.

HOW THE WAR IS AFFECTING OXFORD
(Continued from page 3)

Even American students here are
affected by the war. There is not
the usual schedule of lectures, for
there are not enough men to attend.
Many of the great lecturers have
temporarily abandoned their work.
So close to London, there is a tenseness prevalent which compels a
close study of what is going on in
naval and military circles, and as
everybody is profoundly interested
in these, study is partially affected.
I do not believe that war is popular with the students. I do not
say, however, that they are ignoring the appeals for voluntary service. The college men are among
the first to enlist, giving up everything that they might serve their
country in its time of strife. But
they have not that military spirit
which marks the chief opponent
and they would rather be studying
than fighting; not rather fighting
than studying, the spirit in Germany.
The American Club here, a club
composed of students from all over
the Eastern Hemisphere, has decided to omit its usual Thanksgiving
Dinner this year, because it was
feared the English might think that
we were trying to celebrate the
Fourth of July while they were at
war. Of course, such a belief
would not be current among the
people who were familiar with the
club, but it was thought that perhaps a report of the affair would
be misunderstood by people not living at Oxford. When we think of
the good old-fashioned dinner we
have missed, we get a most practical example of the fact that "war
is hell."

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Two students in the University
of Washington have undertaken the
construction of what will be the
largest electrical transformer on
the Pacific Coast, as a thesis for a
degree in engineering. They are
Leo Dashley and John Dodds, both
Seattle men.
The transformer, which will be
ready for use in the spring, will be
surpassed in size by but two or
three in the entire country, the
larger ones being in testing laboratories of big electrical companies. The apparatus is to be set
up in the engineering building for
research work and the testing of
.insulating materials. It will be
seven feet high, four feet wide and
two feet thick; will contain 303
pounds of wire; throw a spark
twenty inches and will step up the
voltage from 220 to 220,000 volts.
* * *
Fifty freshmen of the University
of Colorado have been haled before the Student Commission for
violation of the associated student
rules, which provide that no firstyear man shall appear on the campus wearing any headgear other
than the official postage stamp cap
with the green button. The Commission is given power to punish
all offenders of this rule.
* * * •
A whist contest between the faculty and the seniors of Kansas University is being planned by the
Student Union.
According to the papers that have
been turned in to the White Cross
Committee, more than ',coo students and members of the faculty
have contributed to the fund for
the relief of the Belgians. Besides
these funds, much clothing is also
being collected for the aid of the
European sufferers.
* * *
The chickens belonging to the
University of Missouri have been
vaccinated to prevent roup. These
chickens are prize birds of the
Poultry Department.
* * *
A new department of wireless
telegraphy has been instituted at
Tulane University. The offices of
the department were at first in the
rooms of two of the students, but
have been recently moved to the
engineering building. At first the
students used their bedsprings for
receiving wires and operated with
electric light switches.
* * *
. .
At the University of Missouri
there has been a straw vote taken
so as to ascertain who were in favor of equal suffrage. Of the five
hundred men that voted, 298 were
in favor of giving the women the
vote.

FOUR INJURED MEN DOING WELL
Bob Layfield Is Stronger—Capt. Paul
Wilkinson, Claude Uhler, and Ed
Pfitsch Have Broken Bones.

There was no change in the general condition of Bob Layfield last
week, but he is much stronger than
he has been at any time since his
back was broken in the Lehigh game
a month ago. The complete paralysis still exists, but Bob is brighter than he has ever been since the
accident.
A letter received from the Maryland Club of Lehigh Alumni by
the Athletic Association last week
is as follows:
To the Athletic Committee
of Johns Hopkins University:
The Lehigh Club of Maryland desires
me to assure you of the deep regret of
its members at the terrible injury sustained by one of the Johns Hopkins
team—Robert Layfield—in the recent
Johns Hopkins-Lehigh football game.
Their sincere sympathy rests with
Mr. Layfield and his family, and they
earnestly hope that his splendid fight
against odds may result in the victory
he so nobly deserves—a complete and
speedy recovery.
Very truly yours,
W. HOWARD CORDREY,Secretary,
Lehigh Club of Maryland.

There were two injuries received
in the St. John's game, but neither
was of a serious nature. Captain
Wilkinson's nose was broken in a
mass play, but it has been set very
skillfully, and the break is not
noticeable.
In the third quarter, Edgar
Pfitsch's left arm was broken just
above the wrist, in less than a minute after he had gone into the play.
He was sent in to substitute for
Gorman. It was the fourth down
with two yards to go. Coach Cates
sent Pfitsch in, and a line play with
him to carry was called. Pfitsch
made the distance with a yard to
spare, but he could not get up. He
was carried from the field. Dr.
Abercrombie and Dr. Stone set the
bone temporarily, and Pfitsch was
sent to his home. He went to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital Friday
morning, and the arm was put in
a cast.
The distance he covered in the
one play in which he carried the
ball made one of the two Hopkins
touchdowns possible. Pfitsch will
be able to attend his classes without losing much time.
The fouFth accident of the season
was that received by Halfback
Claude Uhler in the Western Maryland game. Uhler's ankle bones
were fractured in a mass play, and
he was taken from the game. He
did not believe the injury a serious
one at first, and it was treated as
an ordinary sprain. He went to
the Johns Hopkins Hospital Monday, and an X-ray photograph revealed several broken bones in the
instep. They were set, and a cast
was placed around the left foot.
Uhler goes about on crutches, and
was leaning on the arms of a
couple of lady friends at Saturday's
game. He says that his injury is
not so bad after all.

may prove valuable in making their
organization more efficient. Are
those who are in charge of the
cloakroom in the basement of McCoy Hall up to date? Let's see!
Every day at 12.50 there is a

window. The sophomores,—nay,

How long will ye suffer this? The
two attendants, learned men both,
get in each other's way. Confusion
reigns supreme.
There is another windoiv nearer
Walter's shop. Why not open it
and thus divide the crowd?
Respectfully,
WITCH.

SIR—I wish to call attention to
the need at Hopkins for a special
song—the sort of song which Pennsylvania and other colleges have
adopted, the sort of song for which
we all uncOnsciously felt the need
of after the game last Thursday—
